description:
Emma, Norman and Ray are the brightest kids at the Grace Field House orphanage. And under the care of the woman they refer to as “Mom,” all the kids have enjoyed a comfortable life. Good food, clean clothes and the perfect environment to learn—what more could an orphan ask for? One day, though, Emma and Norman uncover the dark truth of the outside world they are forbidden from seeing.

(Source: Viz Media)
hashtag: #約束のネバーランド #約ネバ
synonyms: พันธสัญญาเนเวอร์แลนด์

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

tags.name: Survival
tags.description: Centers around the struggle to live in spite of extreme obstacles.

tags.name: Primarily Child Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters below a high school age.

tags.name: Orphan
tags.description: Prominently features a character that is an orphan.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Found Family
tags.description: Features a group of characters with no biological relations that are united in a group providing social support.

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Tanned Skin
tags.description: Prominently features characters with tanned skin.

title.native: お約束のネバーランド　特別番外編

node.description:
[Website](http://posuka.iinaa.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/demizuposuka)

A freelance artist. She made her debut in 2008 with a mini-series published in the manga prepublication magazine Corocoro.

"The Art of Posuka Demizu", her first artbook that gathers her drawings, was published in 2016.

Kaiu Shirai (白井カイウ) (a pseudonym) is a manga writer.

After graduating from university, Shirai worked in a company.

Shirai has published two one-shot books including "Poppy's Wish" ("Poppy no Negai", 2016) with the illustrator Posuka Demizu.

Since 2016, Shirai has been collaborating with Posuka Demizu on the series "The Promised Neverland" ("Yakusoku no Neverland"), a manga published in the Weekly Shonen Jump.
The series sold more than 3 million copies in Japan in its first seven volumes and won the 63rd Shogakukan Prize in the Shōnen category. It was adapted as an anime in 2019.

The bookstore "L'Ange Bleu" in Périgny, awarded to the Volume 1 of "The Promised Neverland" the 2019 Mangawa Prize in the Shōnen category. The Volume 7 is the winner of the 2019 Babelio Manga Prize.

After graduating from Miyakojima Technical Senior High School, Kanbe moved to Tokyo and went to a Professional Training College while delivering newspapers to maintain himself. He joined Studio [Topcraft](https://anilist.co/studio/363/Topcraft) and as his first job he worked as production assistant on [Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind](https://anilist.co/anime/572/Nausica-of-the-Valley-of-the-Wind/).

In the late '80s and early '90s he worked on several NHK educational anime for children while he had his debut as director with the OVA [Ninja Ryuukenden](https://anilist.co/anime/619/Ninja-Ryuukenden/) in 1991. 

In 1997 he established Studio Garan with several employees of [Studio Junio](https://anilist.co/studio/280/Studio-Junio) (which he had previously joined). Garan was one of the subcontracting studios for [Cardcaptor Sakura](https://anilist.co/anime/232/Cardcaptor-Sakura/) and the episodes Kanbe directed garnered much attention. He left Garan in 2000.

More recently he's been mainly known for directing psychological and thriller anime like [Elfen Lied](https://anilist.co/anime/226/Elfen-Lied/), [Electromagnetic Girlfriend](https://anilist.co/anime/5177/Electromagnetic-Girlfriend/) and [The Promised Neverland](https://anilist.co/anime/101759/The-Promised-Neverland/).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/puu_zou)
He formerly worked at [Doga Kobo](https://anilist.co/studio/95/) and is currently working at [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/CloverWorks).
[Profile](https://en.atabostudio.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/atabobata)

__[Website](https://www.uverworld.jp/feature/profile)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/uverworld_dr2)__ | __[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/takuya_world_official/)__ | __[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/uverworldSMEJ)__ __Formed:__ June 6, 2000, Kusatsu City, Shiga Prefecture, Japan __Genres:__ Rock (Alternative Rock, Mixture Rock, Pop Rock), Hip Hop, Industrial, Jazz Fusion and J-POP __Introduction:__ Uverworld (stylized as UVERworld), alternatively known by their nickname UVER, is a Japanese six-piece rock band under record label [gr8! records](https://www.gr8-records.com/), which is a subsidiary of Sony Music Records. The band's name "Uverworld" is a term coined by the band members, which they did by combining the German word "über" (meaning over) with the English word "world" to form a phrase that means "crossing above the world". As a band they have released a total of nine studio albums and over twenty singles, which all garnered quite the success. They have also sold over three million records worldwide. The band is influenced by 1960s rock bands like The Beatles, The Zombies and The Beach Boys. The style became so popular it was later influenced by The Cookies, The Kinks and The Cramps. Vocalist Takuya Shimizu later cited Frank Sinatra, Queen, David Bowie, Weezer, Green Day and My Chemical Romance as the influencers for the band. __Biography:__ The six-piece band known as UVERworld first formed back in 2000, and were at the time known as Sound Goku Road, (or alternatively more popularily known as "Sangoku Road" in the independent music scene). The band originally consisted of seven members, and at the time released a demo CD titled Prime'03. This CD ended up selling 3000 copies, and as an unfortunate follow-up to the CD, two of the band members ultimately decided to leave. The members who left were their saxophonist Seika, and their second-man vocalist Ryohei. After Seika's departure their vocalist Ace∞trigger renamed himself to TAKUYA∞, while the band also renamed to UVERworld. In 2005, the band signed with record label gr8! records. The band made their debut with the single titled "D-technolife", which was used as the second opening theme to the now famous anime Bleach. The single made its debut in the Oricon charts at the fourth spot, with a total of 32.000 copies sold. The single landed close to Mr. Children's twenty-seventh single "Yonjigen Four Dimensions", which took the very top spot. The single would later drop to seventh place a week later, with a toal of 16,306 copies sold. The third week the single would see another drop from seventh to ninth spot, with a total of 13,761 copies sold. Later it was revealed that the single lasted five weeks in the Top 30 weekly singles rankings. The single's sales and Chaku-Uta Full downloads were certified gold by the Recording Industry Association of Japan. Three months later, their second single "Chance!" was used as the commercial and opening theme song to the second PSP game of Bleach: Heat the Soul series. The band's second single first entered the Oricon charts on the fifth spot, with a total of 14,150 copies sold. The single later dropped to the 23rd spot, with a total of 6,360 copies sold in the second week. The single's ranking remained the same, however the number of copies sold by the third week was fewer than the previous week with a total of 5,495 copies sold. It was later revealed that the single only managed to stay on the Top 30 weekly singles ranking for three weeks. (Continuation of their biography on [wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uverworld#2006%E2%80%932008:_Timeless,_Bugright_and_Proglution)) __Members:__ - [Takuya Shimizu](https://anilist.co/staff/101650/) (清水琢也), also known as TAKUYA∞ - vocalist, rapper, guitarist, bassist, pianist, synthesizer, programmer, drummer and in-charge of lyrics and composition (2000-) - Katsuya (克哉) - guitarist, keyboardist, programmer and percussionist (2000-) - Nobuto (信人) - bassist and percussionist (2000-) - Seika (誠果) - saxophonist, percussonist, manipulator and recorder (2000-) - [Akira](https://anilist.co/staff/296788) (彰) - guitarist, programmer, percussionist and in-charge of composition (2000-) - Shintaro (真太郎) - drummer and percussionist (2000-) (Source: [Wikipedia](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/UVERworld), edited)

__[Website](http://coshunie.com/)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/co_shu_nie)__ | __[Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/C%C3%B6-shu-Nie-%E3%82%B3%E3%82%B7%E3%83%A5%E3%83%8B%E3%82%A8-151218092226983/)__ | __[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/coshunie_official/)__ | __[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCWIfHAlwe1kELZDqUmD8oRg)__ | __[Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/0LlH6J1tj2TPq7AlwXAkY5)__ | __[Apple Music](https://music.apple.com/jp/artist/c%C3%B6-shu-nie/573663755)__

__Formed:__ 2011, Osaka Prefecture
__Genres:__ Rock (Indie Rock, Pop Rock)

__Biography:__
Co shu Nie (stylized as Cö shu Nie) is a Japanese two-member rock band under record label Sony Music Associated Records that debuted on June 6, 2018 with the single titled "[asphyxia](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZB9UvUJL_lE)". Their single was used as the opening theme in the third season of [Tokyo Ghoul:re](https://anilist.co/anime/100240/Tokyo-Ghoulre). 

Prior to their debut, however, the band initially independently released their first mini album titled _Hydra_ all the way back in 2013, and according to their vocalist Miku Nakamura, the band name "Cö shu Nie" has no literal meaning, but they instead "became the meaning of the word".

__Members:__
- [Miku Nakamura](https://anilist.co/staff/162259) (中村未来) - vocalist, guitarist, keyboardist, manipulator (2011–)
- Shunsuke Matsumoto (松本駿介) - bass guitarist (2011–)


__Former Members:__
- Kojiro Yamazakoo (ヤマザキコウジロウ) - drummer (2011–2017)
- Ryosuke Fujita (藤田亮介) - drummer (2018–2021)

(Source: [Wikipedia (Cö shu Nie)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%C3%B6_shu_Nie), edited)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1515331173983330306)

Nishigori graduated from the Toei Animation Institute and joined [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/) as an in-betweener but he rapidly distinguished himself as a key animator. He was inspired to enter the field because he liked [Hidenori Matsubara](https://anilist.co/staff/107672/) and [Takeshi Honda](https://anilist.co/staff/103303/)'s drawings.

His first major role was serving as character animation director for [Top wo Nerae 2! Diebuster](https://anilist.co/anime/1002/Gunbuster-2-Diebuster/), with the task of adapting [Yoshiyuki Sadamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/98158/Yoshiyuki-Sadamoto)'s character designs for animation. This experience led him to become one of the main character designers at the studio, designing the iconic characters for [Gurren Lagann](https://anilist.co/anime/2001/).

He left Gainax to have his debut as director on [The Idolm@ster](https://anilist.co/anime/10278/The-Idol-Master/), a personal passion project since he's a great fan of the series. Several Gainax staff followed Nishigori to [A-1 Pictures](https://anilist.co/studio/561/) and worked on the series, alongside staff from newly formed [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/Trigger).

In 2018 he directed his original project [Darling in the Franxx](https://anilist.co/anime/99423/), once again reuniting with his Gainax friends spread among [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/), Trigger and [Studio Khara](https://anilist.co/studio/47/).

More recently he worked as character designer and chief animation director for [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/)'s final Evangelion installment, [Evangelion: 3.0+1.0 Thrice Upon A Time](https://anilist.co/anime/3786/Evangelion-3010-Thrice-Upon-A-Time/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1515331173983330306)

After graduating from Osaka Designer Senmon Gakkou, she worked for Production IG and GAINAX before becoming a freelancer.
